Kentucky cruises to 92-44 win over Texas-Arlington

Two nights after holding Montana State to 11 points on 5-of-31 shooting in the first half, Kentucky similarly smothered Texas-Arlington before the break – 12 points on 4-of-32 shooting – en route to a 92-44 throttling of the Mavericks.

Kentucky cruises to 92-44 win over Texas-Arlington

Kyle Tucker, ktucker@courier-journal.com 11:17 p.m. EST November 25, 2014

Two nights after holding Montana State to 11 points on 5-of-31 shooting in the first half, Kentucky similarly smothered Texas-Arlington before the break – 12 points on 4-of-32 shooting – en route to a 92-44 throttling of the Mavericks.

Kentucky's Aaron Harrison, left, shoots under pressure from Texas-Arlington's Kevin Hervey during the first half of an NCAA college basketball game, Tuesday, Nov. 25, 2014, in Lexington, Ky. (AP Photo/James Crisp)(Photo: James Crisp, AP)

5 CONNECT 2 TWEETLINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. -- With two platoons and 10 projected NBA draft picks, there are a lot of players on the University of Kentucky basketball team who want to "eat" – or shine, in other words – freshman Karl-Anthony Towns said.

There are only so many shots to go around, though, unless the defense can create extra possessions. In that case, when the top-ranked Wildcats swarm the way they have been, "there's a lot of food out there to go get," Towns said, "and all you gotta do is just go grab a plate."

Tuesday night was another feast for Kentucky as it swallowed Texas-Arlington whole in a 92-44 rout at Rupp Arena. Two nights after holding Montana State to 11 points on 5-of-31 shooting in the first half, the Cats (6-0) similarly roasted the Mavericks before the break.

Video | UK's Booker on UT Arlington rout, hot shooting

The Wildcats (6-0) have now held their last two opponents to 14.3 percent shooting in the first half and blocked 16 shots (compared to nine made field goals) before halftime. This time, it added up to a staggering 55-12 lead after 20 minutes.

At that point, Kentucky had swatted twice as many shots as UT-Arlington made and five Cats had at least six points, led by 12 from freshman shooting guard Devin Booker, who swished 4 of 5 3-pointers in the half. He finished with a team-high 19 points and sank five of his six tries from deep.

RELATED: Game Rewind | UT Arlington UK's latest victim

RELATED: Instant Analysis | Kentucky-UT Arlington

UT Arlington (3-2) hit 4 of 32 shots and scored just 12 points in the opening 20 minutes, meaning UK has held its last two opponents to 14.3 percent shooting and recorded 16 blocks (compared to nine made field goals) in the first half. The Wildcats' defense has been devastating.

"It seems like the buffet line starts there," said Towns, who gorged himself on that food metaphor after stuffing the stat sheet with 13 points, 11 rebounds, four assists, three blocks and a steal in only 17 minutes. "Now I'm hungry."

Kentucky blocked twice as many shots as the Mavericks made to build a staggering 55-12 lead at intermission. Freshman shooting guard Devin Booker had matched UT Arlington by himself on the scoreboard at that point, scoring 12 of his game-high 19 points and making four of his five 3-pointers (he only missed one) before the break.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Keep up with Louisville news while on the go with our apps for iOS and Android

Booker, who hit just 1 of 11 threes to start the season, has buried 12 of 17 the last three games. But even he got in on the defense, swiping a pair of steals.

"In high school, you don't always have to lock in defensively," he admitted. "In college, you have to or you'll get exposed out there."

And when they play defense, everyone eats. Seven Wildcats scored at least eight points, six of them in double figures, while no one played more than 21 minutes as coach John Calipari once again deployed his two platoon system. Sophomore shooting guard Aaron Harrison had 11 at intermission, which is what he and twin Andrew Harrison both finished with.

Sophomore center Dakari Johnson had 12 points and six rebounds but, more impressively, hit 12 of 14 free throws. He'd made only 12 of 25 through five games.

    Kentucky's starters outscored the Mavericks 36-8 in 11:28 of time in the first half, while the second platoon outscored UT Arlington 19-4 in eight and a half minutes together.

    "Every one of those kids has pro aspirations and pro potential … and they're doing this for each other. This is crazy," Calipari said. "That's why I say, for anybody in our society, where everybody talks about the 'me' and 'mine' and narcissism and all that, why wouldn't you root for this to happen and be good?"

    It's happening and it is, so far, very good for the Cats.

    They held the Mavericks without a made field goal or point for the final 7:12 of the first half to build that 43-point lead, the second-largest halftime margin in program history behind a 44-point edge on LSU in 1996. It shrank as small as 36 in the second half, but UK stepped on the gas again and led 85-38 with 5:08 remaining.

    UT Arlington shot an impressive – by Wildcats opponent standards – 13 of 31 in the second half to improve its total field-goal tally to 27 percent for the night.

    Only one team out of six has scored more than 52 points against these Cats, who've held every opponent to 38.5 percent shooting or worse. Teams have hit just 27.9 percent for the season and Kentucky has blocked 55 two-point shots now compared to just 62 made against them from inside the arc.

    "This team has a chance of being one of those teams you talk about defensively – like (among the best) of all-time, if they choose to be," Calipari said. "But they're going to have to choose to be."

    It's all a matter of appetite.

    Kyle Tucker can be reached at (502) 582-4361. Follow him on Twitter @KyleTucker_CJ.
